title: Your iPhone Is Getting New Emoji Soon ‚Äî Meet the Characters Arriving in iOS 18.4
description: Get ready to upgrade your emoji game! Thanks to the Unicode 16.0 update, a new wave of fun and expressive characters is coming to your iPhone. While the last emoji refresh was nearly a year ago, iOS 18.4 is expected to bring these fresh designs to your keyboard in spring 2025. Don't Miss: The Complete iOS 18.2 Features Guide ‚Äî Here's Everything New and Improved for Your iPhone The previous emoji update for iPhone arrived in March 2024 with iOS 17.4, adding highlights like the phoenix (üê¶‚Äçüî•), lime wedge (üçã‚Äçüü©), and head-shaking faces (üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜîÔ∏èüôÇ‚Äç‚ÜïÔ∏è) from Unicode 15.1. This time, the Unicode 16.0 batch promises a mix of practical icons, playful symbols, and cultural additions to keep your messages vibrant. Unicode 16.0 introduces seven new emoji characters that represent a variety of emotions, themes, and everyday scenarios. These include Face with Bags Under Eyes, Fingerprint, Harp, Splatter, Root Vegetable, Leafless Tree, and Shovel. An eighth emoji, Flag of Sark, is also included in...more
author: Jovana Naumovski

title: 160+ New Emoji Are Coming, Including Bigfoot, Distorted Face, and Apple Core
description: The Unicode Consortium is already hard at work on the next batch of emoji, but don't get too excited just yet. It may be a while before you see these new characters, which include an apple core, orca, and hairy creature, on your devices. Unicode 17.0, with its Emoji 17.0 update, isn't expected to be finalized until September 2025, but nine new emoji candidates have already been drafted. Those are: Apple Core: A compostable icon for food waste or garbage. Ballet Dancer: A new gender-neutral character celebrating the art of dance, grace, and self-expression. Distorted Face: Reflecting feelings of vulnerability, panic, or surprise. Fight Cloud: A playful emoji representing brawls or disagreements. Hairy Creature: Inspired by mythical beings like the yeti or bigfoot. Landslide: Symbolizing natural disasters or geological events. Orca: Representing marine life and conservation themes. Treasure Chest: Representing valuables, wealth, or pirate lore. Trombone: A musical addition for fans of...more
author: Jovana Naumovski

title: Finnish Long Drink
description: The Finnish Long Drink (also called a Lonkero) was first created in 1952 at the Helsinki Summer Olympics. Served in a tall glass (a long glass), its name comes from the glassware it is served in. Related: Vodka Tonic, 7 and 7, Malibu Bay Breeze, Dirty Shirley, Mixed Drinks.
